speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Enter, from opposite sides, a Fairy, and PUCK

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: How now, spirit! whither wander you?

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Over hill, over dale,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Thorough bush, thorough brier,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Over park, over pale,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Thorough flood, thorough fire,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: I do wander everywhere,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Swifter than the moon's sphere;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And I serve the fairy queen,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: To dew her orbs upon the green.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: The cowslips tall her pensioners be:

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: In their gold coats spots you see;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Those be rubies, fairy favours,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: In those freckles live their savours:

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: I must go seek some dewdrops here

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And hang a pearl in every cowslip's ear.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Farewell, thou lob of spirits; I'll be gone:

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Our queen and all our elves come here anon.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: The king doth keep his revels here to-night:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Take heed the queen come not within his sight;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: For Oberon is passing fell and wrath,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Because that she as her attendant hath

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: A lovely boy, stolen from an Indian king;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: She never had so sweet a changeling;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And jealous Oberon would have the child

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: But she perforce withholds the loved boy,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Crowns him with flowers and makes him all her joy:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And now they never meet in grove or green,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: By fountain clear, or spangled starlight sheen,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: But, they do square, that all their elves for fear

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Creep into acorn-cups and hide them there.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Either I mistake your shape and making quite,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Call'd Robin Goodfellow: are not you he

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: That frights the maidens of the villagery;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Skim milk, and sometimes labour in the quern

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And bootless make the breathless housewife churn;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And sometime make the drink to bear no barm;

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm?

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Those that Hobgoblin call you and sweet Puck,

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: You do their work, and they shall have good luck:

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Are not you he?

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Thou speak'st aright;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I am that merry wanderer of the night.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I jest to Oberon and make him smile

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Neighing in likeness of a filly foal:

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And sometime lurk I in a gossip's bowl,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: In very likeness of a roasted crab,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And when she drinks, against her lips I bob

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And on her wither'd dewlap pour the ale.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: The wisest aunt, telling the saddest tale,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Then slip I from her bum, down topples she,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And 'tailor' cries, and falls into a cough;

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh,

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: And waxen in their mirth and neeze and swear

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: A merrier hour was never wasted there.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: But, room, fairy! here comes Oberon.

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: And here my mistress. Would that he were gone!

speaker: Fairy
text_entry: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: What, jealous Oberon! Fairies, skip hence:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: I have forsworn his bed and company.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Tarry, rash wanton: am not I thy lord?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Then I must be thy lady: but I know

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: When thou hast stolen away from fairy land,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And in the shape of Corin sat all day,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Playing on pipes of corn and versing love

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To amorous Phillida. Why art thou here,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Come from the farthest Steppe of India?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Your buskin'd mistress and your warrior love,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To Theseus must be wedded, and you come

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To give their bed joy and prosperity.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: How canst thou thus for shame, Titania,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Glance at my credit with Hippolyta,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Knowing I know thy love to Theseus?

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Didst thou not lead him through the glimmering night

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: From Perigenia, whom he ravished?

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And make him with fair AEgle break his faith,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With Ariadne and Antiopa?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: These are the forgeries of jealousy:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And never, since the middle summer's spring,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Met we on hill, in dale, forest or mead,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: By paved fountain or by rushy brook,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Or in the beached margent of the sea,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: But with thy brawls thou hast disturb'd our sport.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: As in revenge, have suck'd up from the sea

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Contagious fogs; which falling in the land

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Have every pelting river made so proud

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: That they have overborne their continents:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The ox hath therefore stretch'd his yoke in vain,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Hath rotted ere his youth attain'd a beard;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The fold stands empty in the drowned field,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And crows are fatted with the murrion flock;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The nine men's morris is fill'd up with mud,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And the quaint mazes in the wanton green

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: For lack of tread are undistinguishable:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The human mortals want their winter here;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: No night is now with hymn or carol blest:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Therefore the moon, the governess of floods,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Pale in her anger, washes all the air,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: That rheumatic diseases do abound:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And thorough this distemperature we see

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Far in the fresh lap of the crimson rose,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And on old Hiems' thin and icy crown

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Is, as in mockery, set: the spring, the summer,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The childing autumn, angry winter, change

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Their wonted liveries, and the mazed world,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: By their increase, now knows not which is which:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And this same progeny of evils comes

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: From our debate, from our dissension;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: We are their parents and original.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Do you amend it then; it lies in you:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Why should Titania cross her Oberon?

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I do but beg a little changeling boy,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: To be my henchman.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Set your heart at rest:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: The fairy land buys not the child of me.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: His mother was a votaress of my order:

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And, in the spiced Indian air, by night,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Full often hath she gossip'd by my side,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And sat with me on Neptune's yellow sands,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Marking the embarked traders on the flood,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: When we have laugh'd to see the sails conceive

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Following,--her womb then rich with my young squire,--

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Would imitate, and sail upon the land,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: To fetch me trifles, and return again,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: But she, being mortal, of that boy did die;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And for her sake do I rear up her boy,

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And for her sake I will not part with him.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: How long within this wood intend you stay?

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Perchance till after Theseus' wedding-day.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: If you will patiently dance in our round

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: And see our moonlight revels, go with us;

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Give me that boy, and I will go with thee.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Not for thy fairy kingdom. Fairies, away!

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: We shall chide downright, if I longer stay.

speaker: TITANIA
text_entry: Exit TITANIA with her train

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Well, go thy way: thou shalt not from this grove

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Till I torment thee for this injury.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: My gentle Puck, come hither. Thou rememberest

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Since once I sat upon a promontory,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And heard a mermaid on a dolphin's back

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Uttering such dulcet and harmonious breath

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: That the rude sea grew civil at her song

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And certain stars shot madly from their spheres,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: To hear the sea-maid's music.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I remember.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: That very time I saw, but thou couldst not,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Flying between the cold moon and the earth,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Cupid all arm'd: a certain aim he took

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: At a fair vestal throned by the west,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And loosed his love-shaft smartly from his bow,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But I might see young Cupid's fiery shaft

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Quench'd in the chaste beams of the watery moon,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And the imperial votaress passed on,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: In maiden meditation, fancy-free.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Yet mark'd I where the bolt of Cupid fell:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: It fell upon a little western flower,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Before milk-white, now purple with love's wound,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And maidens call it love-in-idleness.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Fetch me that flower; the herb I shew'd thee once:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: The juice of it on sleeping eye-lids laid

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Will make or man or woman madly dote

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Upon the next live creature that it sees.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Fetch me this herb; and be thou here again

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Ere the leviathan can swim a league.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: I'll put a girdle round about the earth

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: In forty minutes.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Having once this juice,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I'll watch Titania when she is asleep,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And drop the liquor of it in her eyes.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: The next thing then she waking looks upon,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bull,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: On meddling monkey, or on busy ape,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: She shall pursue it with the soul of love:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And ere I take this charm from off her sight,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: As I can take it with another herb,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I'll make her render up her page to me.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But who comes here? I am invisible;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And I will overhear their conference.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Enter DEMETRIUS, HELENA, following him

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: The one I'll slay, the other slayeth me.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thou told'st me they were stolen unto this wood;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And here am I, and wode within this wood,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Because I cannot meet my Hermia.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But yet you draw not iron, for my heart

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Is true as steel: leave you your power to draw,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And I shall have no power to follow you.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Do I entice you? do I speak you fair?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Or, rather, do I not in plainest truth

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Tell you, I do not, nor I cannot love you?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And even for that do I love you the more.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The more you beat me, I will fawn on you:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Use me but as your spaniel, spurn me, strike me,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Unworthy as I am, to follow you.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: What worser place can I beg in your love,--

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And yet a place of high respect with me,--

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Than to be used as you use your dog?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: For I am sick when I do look on thee.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And I am sick when I look not on you.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: You do impeach your modesty too much,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To leave the city and commit yourself

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Into the hands of one that loves you not;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To trust the opportunity of night

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And the ill counsel of a desert place

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: With the rich worth of your virginity.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Your virtue is my privilege: for that

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: It is not night when I do see your face,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Therefore I think I am not in the night;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: For you in my respect are all the world:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Then how can it be said I am alone,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When all the world is here to look on me?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I'll run from thee and hide me in the brakes,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The wildest hath not such a heart as you.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Run when you will, the story shall be changed:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Apollo flies, and Daphne holds the chase;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The dove pursues the griffin; the mild hind

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Makes speed to catch the tiger; bootless speed,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When cowardice pursues and valour flies.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: I will not stay thy questions; let me go:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Or, if thou follow me, do not believe

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You do me mischief. Fie, Demetrius!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: We cannot fight for love, as men may do;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: We should be wood and were not made to woo.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exit DEMETRIUS

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I'll follow thee and make a heaven of hell,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To die upon the hand I love so well.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Fare thee well, nymph: ere he do leave this grove,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Thou shalt fly him and he shall seek thy love.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Re-enter PUCK

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Hast thou the flower there? Welcome, wanderer.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Ay, there it is.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I pray thee, give it me.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: I know a bank where the wild thyme blows,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Quite over-canopied with luscious woodbine,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With sweet musk-roses and with eglantine:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Lull'd in these flowers with dances and delight;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And there the snake throws her enamell'd skin,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And with the juice of this I'll streak her eyes,

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And make her full of hateful fantasies.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Take thou some of it, and seek through this grove:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: A sweet Athenian lady is in love

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: With a disdainful youth: anoint his eyes;

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: But do it when the next thing he espies

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: May be the lady: thou shalt know the man

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: By the Athenian garments he hath on.

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: Effect it with some care, that he may prove

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: More fond on her than she upon her love:

speaker: OBERON
text_entry: And look thou meet me ere the first cock crow.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Fear not, my lord, your servant shall do so.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Exeunt
